member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo
member.summary: Provides access to information on a local or remote drive.
member.remarks: This class models a drive and provides methods and properties to query for drive information. Use DriveInfo to determine what drives are available, and what type of drives they are. You can also query to determine the capacity and available free space on the drive.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.AvailableFreeSpace
member.summary: Indicates the amount of available free space on a drive.
member.returns: The amount of free space available on the drive, in bytes.
member.remarks: This property indicates the amount of free space available on the drive. Note that this number may be different from the number because this property takes into account disk quotas.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.DriveFormat
member.summary: Gets the name of the file system, such as NTFS or FAT32.
member.remarks: Use DriveFormat to determine what formatting a drive uses.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.DriveType
member.summary: Gets the drive type.
member.returns: One of the values.
member.remarks: The DriveType property indicates whether a drive is any of: CDRom, Fixed, Unknown, Network, NoRootDirectory, Ram, Removable, or Unknown. Values are listed in the enumeration.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.IsReady
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a drive is ready.
member.returns: true if the drive is ready; false otherwise.
member.remarks:
IsReady indicates whether a drive is ready. For example, it indicates whether a CD is in a CD drive or whether a removable storage device is ready for read/write operations. If you do not test whether a drive is ready, and it is not ready, querying the drive using DriveInfo will raise an IOException.
Do not rely on IsReady() to avoid catching exceptions from other members such as TotalSize, TotalFreeSpace, and DriveFormat. Between the time that your code checks IsReady and then accesses one of the other properties (even if the access occurs immediately after the check), a drive may have been disconnected or a disk may have been removed.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.Name
member.summary: Gets the name of the drive.
member.returns: The name of the drive.
member.remarks: This property is the name assigned to the drive, such as C:\ or E:\

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.RootDirectory
member.summary: Gets the root directory of a drive.
member.returns: A DirectoryInfo object that contains the root directory of the drive.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.TotalFreeSpace
member.summary: Gets the total amount of free space available on a drive.
member.returns: The total free space available on a drive, in bytes.
member.remarks: This property indicates the total amount of free space available on the drive, not just what is available to the current user.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.TotalSize
member.summary: Gets the total size of storage space on a drive.
member.returns: The total size of the drive, in bytes.
member.remarks: This property indicates the total size of the drive in bytes, not just what is available to the current user.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DriveInfo.VolumeLabel
member.summary: Gets or sets the volume label of a drive.
member.returns: The volume label.
member.remarks: The label length is determined by the operating system. For example, NTFS allows a volume label to be up to 32 characters long. Note that null is a valid VolumeLabel.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetErrorMode(Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode)
member.summary: Controls whether the system will handle the specified types of serious errors or whether the process will handle them.
member.returns: The return value is the previous state of the error-mode bit attributes.
member.remarks: Because the error mode is set for the entire process, you must ensure that multi-threaded applications do not set different error-mode attributes. Doing so can lead to inconsistent error handling.
SetLastError is set to false.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.BackupRead(Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeFileHandle,System.Runtime.InteropServices.SafeHandle,System.UInt32,System.UInt32@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The BackupRead function can be used to back up a file or directory, including the security information. The function reads data associated with a specified file or directory into a buffer, which can then be written to the backup medium using the WriteFile function.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero, indicating that an I/O error occurred. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: This function is not intended for use in backing up files encrypted under the Encrypted File System. Use ReadEncryptedFileRaw for that purpose.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.BackupSeek(Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeFileHandle,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32@,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The BackupSeek function seeks forward in a data stream initially accessed by using the BackupRead or BackupWrite function.
member.returns: If the function could seek the requested amount, the function returns a nonzero value. If the function could not seek the requested amount, the function returns zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: Applications use the BackupSeek function to skip portions of a data stream that cause errors. This function does not seek across stream headers. For example, this function cannot be used to skip the stream name. If an application attempts to seek past the end of a substream, the function fails, the lpdwLowByteSeeked and lpdwHighByteSeeked parameters indicate the actual number of bytes the function seeks, and the file position is placed at the start of the next stream header.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.BackupWrite(Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles.SafeFileHandle,Alphaleonis.Win32.SafeGlobalMemoryBufferHandle,System.UInt32,System.UInt32@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.IntPtr@)
member.summary: The BackupWrite function can be used to restore a file or directory that was backed up using BackupRead. Use the ReadFile function to get a stream of data from the backup medium, then use BackupWrite to write the data to the specified file or directory.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero, indicating that an I/O error occurred. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: This function is not intended for use in restoring files encrypted under the Encrypted File System. Use WriteEncryptedFileRaw for that purpose.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.DecryptFile(System.String,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Decrypts an encrypted file or directory.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: The DecryptFile function requires exclusive access to the file being decrypted, and will fail if another process is using the file. If the file is not encrypted, DecryptFile simply returns a nonzero value, which indicates success. If lpFileName specifies a read-only file, the function fails and GetLastError returns ERROR_FILE_READ_ONLY. If lpFileName specifies a directory that contains a read-only file, the functions succeeds but the directory is not decrypted.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.EncryptFile(System.String)
member.summary: Encrypts a file or directory. All data streams in a file are encrypted. All new files created in an encrypted directory are encrypted.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: The EncryptFile function requires exclusive access to the file being encrypted, and will fail if another process is using the file. If the file is already encrypted, EncryptFile simply returns a nonzero value, which indicates success. If the file is compressed, EncryptFile will decompress the file before encrypting it. If lpFileName specifies a read-only file, the function fails and GetLastError returns ERROR_FILE_READ_ONLY. If lpFileName specifies a directory that contains a read-only file, the functions succeeds but the directory is not encrypted.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: EncryptionDisable() disables encryption of directories and files. It does not affect the visibility of files with the FILE_ATTRIBUTE_SYSTEM attribute set. This method will create/change the file "Desktop.ini" and wil set Encryption value: "Disable=0|1"
Minimum supported client: Windows XP Professional [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is a search handle that can be used with the FindNextFileNameW function or closed with the FindClose function. If the function fails, the return value is INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE (0xffffffff). To get extended error information, call the GetLastError function.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows Vista [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindNextFile(Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.SafeFindFileHandle,Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FindData@)
member.summary: Continues a file search from a previous call to the FindFirstFile, FindFirstFileEx, or FindFirstFileTransacted functions.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero and the lpFindFileData parameter contains information about the next file or directory found. If the function fails, the return value is zero and the contents of lpFindFileData are indeterminate. To get extended error information, call the GetLastError function. If the function fails because no more matching files can be found, the GetLastError function returns ERROR_NO_MORE_FILES.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps | Windows Store apps]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps | Windows Store apps]

Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.GetCompressedFileSize(System.String,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Retrieves the actual number of bytes of disk storage used to store a specified file.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the low-order DWORD of the actual number of bytes of disk storage used to store the specified file, and if lpFileSizeHigh is non-NULL, the function puts the high-order DWORD of that actual value into the DWORD pointed to by that parameter. This is the compressed file size for compressed files, the actual file size for noncompressed files. If the function fails, and lpFileSizeHigh is NULL, the return value is INVALID_FILE_SIZE. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. If the return value is INVALID_FILE_SIZE and lpFileSizeHigh is non-NULL, an application must call GetLastError to determine whether the function has succeeded (value is NO_ERROR) or failed (value is other than NO_ERROR).
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

This is the compressed file size for compressed files, the actual file size for noncompressed files. If the function fails, and lpFileSizeHigh is NULL, the return value is INVALID_FILE_SIZE. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. If the return value is INVALID_FILE_SIZE and lpFileSizeHigh is non-NULL, an application must call GetLastError to determine whether the function has succeeded (value is NO_ERROR) or failed (value is other than NO_ERROR).

Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.GetFileAttributesEx(System.String,System.UInt32,Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData@)
member.summary: Retrieves attributes for a specified file or directory.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: The GetFileAttributes function retrieves file system attribute information. GetFileAttributesEx can obtain other sets of file or directory attribute information. Currently, GetFileAttributesEx retrieves a set of standard attributes that is a superset of the file system attribute information. When the GetFileAttributesEx function is called on a directory that is a mounted folder, it returns the attributes of the directory, not those of the root directory in the volume that the mounted folder associates with the directory. To obtain the attributes of the associated volume, call GetVolumeNameForVolumeMountPoint to obtain the name of the associated volume. Then use the resulting name in a call to GetFileAttributesEx. The results are the attributes of the root directory on the associated volume. Symbolic link behavior: If the path points to a symbolic link, the function returns attributes for the symbolic link.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.GetFileAttributesTransacted(System.String,System.UInt32,Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData@,System.Runtime.InteropServices.SafeHandle)
member.summary: Retrieves file system attributes for a specified file or directory as a transacted operation.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: Transacted Operations If a file is open for modification in a transaction, no other thread can open the file for modification until the transaction is committed. Conversely, if a file is open for modification outside of a transaction, no transacted thread can open the file for modification until the non-transacted handle is closed. If a non-transacted thread has a handle opened to modify a file, a call to GetFileAttributesTransacted for that file will fail with an ERROR_TRANSACTIONAL_CONFLICT error.
Minimum supported client: Windows Vista [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]

member.remarks: Depending on the underlying network features of the operating system and the type of server connected to, the GetFileInformationByHandle function may fail, return partial information, or full information for the given file.
Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.returns: true if the file exists; false otherwise. Call GetLastError for extended error information.
member.remarks: This function tests the validity of the path. A path specified by Universal Naming Convention (UNC) is limited to a file only; that is, \\server\share\file is permitted. A network share path to a server or server share is not permitted; that is, \\server or \\server\share. This function returns FALSE if a mounted remote drive is out of service.

member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows Vista [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2008 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.GetVolumeNameForVolumeMountPoint(System.String,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Retrieves a volume GUID path for the volume that is associated with the specified volume mount point (drive letter, volume GUID path, or mounted folder).
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. To get extended error information call Win32Exception()
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.GetVolumePathName(System.String,System.Text.StringBuilder,System.UInt32)

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.GetVolumePathNamesForVolumeName(System.String,System.Char[],System.UInt32,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Retrieves a list of drive letters and mounted folder paths for the specified volume.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetVolumeLabel(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Sets the label of a file system volume.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]
"lpRootPathName" must end with a trailing backslash.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetVolumeMountPoint(System.String,System.String)

member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.QueryDosDevice(System.String,System.Char[],System.UInt32)
member.summary: Retrieves information about MS-DOS device names.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the number of TCHARs stored into the buffer pointed to by lpTargetPath. If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError. If the buffer is too small, the function fails and the last error code is ERROR_INSUFFICIENT_BUFFER.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps only]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps only]

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetupDiGetClassDevsExFlags
member.summary: Specifies control options that filter the device information elements that are added to the device information set.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetupDiGetClassDevsExFlags.Default
member.summary: DIGCF_DEFAULT - Return only the device that is associated with the system default device interface, if one is set, for the specified device interface classes.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetupDiGetClassDevsExFlags.Present
member.summary: DIGCF_PRESENT - Return only devices that are currently present.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetupDiGetClassDevsExFlags.AllClasses
member.summary: DIGCF_ALLCLASSES - Return a list of installed devices for the specified device setup classes or device interface classes.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetupDiGetClassDevsExFlags.Profile
member.summary: DIGCF_PROFILE - Return only devices that are a part of the current hardware profile.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.SetupDiGetClassDevsExFlags.DeviceInterface
member.summary: DIGCF_DEVICEINTERFACE - Return devices that support device interfaces for the specified device interface classes. This flag must be set in the Flags parameter if the Enumerator parameter specifies a Device Instance ID.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileInfoByHandleClass
member.summary: Identifies the type of file information that GetFileInformationByHandleEx should retrieve or SetFileInformationByHandle should set.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileInfoByHandleClass.FileIdBothDirectoryInfo
member.summary: Files in the specified directory should be retrieved. Used for directory handles. Use only when calling GetFileInformationByHandleEx. The number of files returned for each call to GetFileInformationByHandleEx depends on the size of the buffer that is passed to the function. Any subsequent calls to GetFileInformationByHandleEx on the same handle will resume the enumeration operation after the last file is returned. See FILE_ID_BOTH_DIR_INFO.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExAdditionalFlags
member.summary: Additional flags that control the search.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExAdditionalFlags.None
member.summary: No additional flags used.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExAdditionalFlags.CaseSensitive
member.summary: Searches are case-sensitive.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExAdditionalFlags.LargeFetch
member.summary: Uses a larger buffer for directory queries, which can increase performance of the find operation.
member.remarks: This value is not supported until Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExInfoLevels
member.summary: FINDEX_INFO_LEVELS - Defines values that are used with the FindFirstFileEx function to specify the information level of the returned data.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps | Windows Store apps]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps | Windows Store apps]

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExInfoLevels.Standard
member.summary: The FindFirstFileEx function retrieves a standard set of attribute information. The data is returned in a structure.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExInfoLevels.Basic
member.summary: The FindFirstFileEx function does not query the short file name, improving overall enumeration speed.
member.remarks: The data is returned in a structure, and cAlternateFileName member is always a NULL string.
This value is not supported until Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExSearchOps
member.summary: FINDEX_SEARCH_OPS - Defines values that are used with the FindFirstFileEx function to specify the type of filtering to perform.
member.remarks: Minimum supported client: Windows XP [desktop apps | Windows Store apps]
Minimum supported server: Windows Server 2003 [desktop apps | Windows Store apps]

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExSearchOps.SearchNameMatch
member.summary: The search for a file that matches a specified file name. The lpSearchFilter parameter of FindFirstFileEx must be NULL when this search operation is used.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExSearchOps.SearchLimitToDirectories
member.summary: This is an advisory flag. If the file system supports directory filtering, the function searches for a file that matches the specified name and is also a directory. If the file system does not support directory filtering, this flag is silently ignored.
member.remarks: The lpSearchFilter parameter of the FindFirstFileEx function must be NULL when this search value is used. If directory filtering is desired, this flag can be used on all file systems, but because it is an advisory flag and only affects file systems that support it, the application must examine the file attribute data stored in the lpFindFileData parameter of the FindFirstFileEx function to determine whether the function has returned a handle to a directory.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FindExSearchOps.SearchLimitToDevices
member.summary: This filtering type is not available.
member.remarks: For more information, see Device Interface Classes.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode
member.summary: Enum for struct ChangeErrorMode.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode.SystemDefault
member.summary: Use the system default, which is to display all error dialog boxes.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode.FailCriticalErrors
member.summary: The system does not display the critical-error-handler message box. Instead, the system sends the error to the calling process/thread.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode.NoGpfaultErrorbox
member.summary: The system does not display the Windows Error Reporting dialog.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode.NoAlignmentFaultExcept
member.summary: The system automatically fixes memory alignment faults and makes them invisible to the application. It does this for the calling process and any descendant processes. This feature is only supported by certain processor architectures.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ErrorMode.NoOpenFileErrorbox
member.summary: The system does not display a message box when it fails to find a file. Instead, the error is returned to the calling process/thread.

member.summary: FILE_SUPPORTS_EXTENDED_ATTRIBUTES The specified volume supports extended attributes. An extended attribute is a piece of application-specific metadata that an application can associate with a file and is not part of the file's data.
member.remarks: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: This value is not supported until Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.VolumeInfoAttributes.SupportsOpenByFileId

member.summary: The file attributes.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.CreationTime
member.summary: A FILETIME structure that specifies when a file or directory is created.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.LastAccessTime
member.summary: A FILETIME structure. For a file, the structure specifies the last time that a file is read from or written to. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. For both files and directories, the specified date is correct, but the time of day is always set to midnight.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.LastWriteTime
member.summary: A FILETIME structure. For a file, the structure specifies the last time that a file is written to. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.VolumeSerialNumber
member.summary: The serial number of the volume that contains a file.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.FileSizeHigh
member.summary: The high-order part of the file size.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.FileSizeLow
member.summary: The low-order part of the file size.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.NumberOfLinks
member.summary: The number of links to this file. For the FAT file system this member is always 1. For the NTFS file system, it can be more than 1.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.FileIndexHigh
member.summary: The high-order part of a unique identifier that is associated with a file.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.ByHandleFileInformation.FileIndexLow
member.summary: The low-order part of a unique identifier that is associated with a file.

member.summary: Controls whether the system will handle the specified types of serious errors or whether the process will handle them.
member.remarks: Not yet implemented: Windows 7, callers should favor SetThreadErrorMode over SetErrorMode since it is less disruptive to the normal behavior of the system.
Minimum supported client: Windows 2000 Professional
Minimum supported server: Windows 2000 Server

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo
member.summary: FILE_ID_BOTH_DIR_INFO - Contains information about files in the specified directory. Used for directory handles. Use only when calling GetFileInformationByHandleEx.
member.remarks: The number of files that are returned for each call to GetFileInformationByHandleEx depends on the size of the buffer that is passed to the function. Any subsequent calls to GetFileInformationByHandleEx on the same handle will resume the enumeration operation after the last file is returned.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.NextEntryOffset
member.summary: The offset for the next FILE_ID_BOTH_DIR_INFO structure that is returned. Contains zero (0) if no other entries follow this one.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.FileIndex
member.summary: The byte offset of the file within the parent directory. This member is undefined for file systems, such as NTFS, in which the position of a file within the parent directory is not fixed and can be changed at any time to maintain sort order.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.CreationTime
member.summary: The time that the file was created.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.LastAccessTime
member.summary: The time that the file was last accessed.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.LastWriteTime
member.summary: The time that the file was last written to.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.ChangeTime
member.summary: The time that the file was last changed.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.EndOfFile
member.summary: The absolute new end-of-file position as a byte offset from the start of the file to the end of the file. Because this value is zero-based, it actually refers to the first free byte in the file. In other words, EndOfFile is the offset to the byte that immediately follows the last valid byte in the file.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.AllocationSize
member.summary: The number of bytes that are allocated for the file. This value is usually a multiple of the sector or cluster size of the underlying physical device.

member.summary: The file attributes.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.ShortNameLength

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.ShortName

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.FileIdBothDirInfo.FileId

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData
member.summary: WIN32_FILE_ATTRIBUTE_DATA structure contains attribute information for a file or directory. The GetFileAttributesEx function uses this structure.
member.remarks: Not all file systems can record creation and last access time, and not all file systems record them in the same manner. For example, on the FAT file system, create time has a resolution of 10 milliseconds, write time has a resolution of 2 seconds, and access time has a resolution of 1 day. On the NTFS file system, access time has a resolution of 1 hour. For more information, see File Times.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData.FileAttributes
member.summary: The file attributes of a file.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData.CreationTime
member.summary: A structure that specifies when a file or directory was created. If the underlying file system does not support creation time, this member is zero.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData.LastAccessTime
member.summary: A structure. For a file, the structure specifies when the file was last read from, written to, or for executable files, run. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support last access time, this member is zero. On the FAT file system, the specified date for both files and directories is correct, but the time of day is always set to midnight.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData.LastWriteTime
member.summary: A structure. For a file, the structure specifies when the file was last written to, truncated, or overwritten, for example, when WriteFile or SetEndOfFile are used. The date and time are not updated when file attributes or security descriptors are changed. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support last write time, this member is zero.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData.FileSizeHigh
member.summary: The high-order DWORD of the file size. This member does not have a meaning for directories. This value is zero unless the file size is greater than MAXDWORD. The size of the file is equal to (nFileSizeHigh * (MAXDWORD+1)) + nFileSizeLow.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FileAttributeData.FileSizeLow
member.summary: The low-order DWORD of the file size. This member does not have a meaning for directories.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32FindData
member.summary: WIN32_FIND_DATA - Contains information about the file that is found by the FindFirstFile, FindFirstFileEx, or FindNextFile function.
member.remarks: If a file has a long file name, the complete name appears in the cFileName member, and the 8.3 format truncated version of the name appears in the cAlternateFileName member. Otherwise, cAlternateFileName is empty. If the FindFirstFileEx function was called with a value of FindExInfoBasic in the fInfoLevelId parameter, the cAlternateFileName member will always contain a null string value. This remains true for all subsequent calls to the FindNextFile function. As an alternative method of retrieving the 8.3 format version of a file name, you can use the GetShortPathName function. For more information about file names, see File Names, Paths, and Namespaces.

Not all file systems can record creation and last access times, and not all file systems record them in the same manner. For example, on the FAT file system, create time has a resolution of 10 milliseconds, write time has a resolution of 2 seconds, and access time has a resolution of 1 day. The NTFS file system delays updates to the last access time for a file by up to 1 hour after the last access. For more information, see File Times.

member.summary: The file attributes of a file.

member.summary: A structure that specifies when a file or directory was created. If the underlying file system does not support creation time, this member is zero.

member.summary: A structure. For a file, the structure specifies when the file was last read from, written to, or for executable files, run. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support last access time, this member is zero. On the FAT file system, the specified date for both files and directories is correct, but the time of day is always set to midnight.

The date and time are not updated when file attributes or security descriptors are changed. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support last write time, this member is zero.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32StreamId
member.summary: The Win32StreamId structure contains stream data.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32StreamId.StreamId
member.summary: Type of data. This member can be one of the following values: BACKUP_DATA 0x00000001 Standard data. This corresponds to the NTFS $DATA stream type on the default (unnamed) data stream. BACKUP_EA_DATA 0x00000002 Extended attribute data. This corresponds to the NTFS $EA stream type. BACKUP_SECURITY_DATA 0x00000003 Security descriptor data. BACKUP_ALTERNATE_DATA 0x00000004 Alternative data streams. This corresponds to the NTFS $DATA stream type on a named data stream. BACKUP_LINK 0x00000005 Hard link information. This corresponds to the NTFS $FILE_NAME stream type. BACKUP_PROPERTY_DATA 0x00000006 Property data. BACKUP_OBJECT_ID 0x00000007 Objects identifiers. This corresponds to the NTFS $OBJECT_ID stream type. BACKUP_REPARSE_DATA 0x00000008 Reparse points. This corresponds to the NTFS $REPARSE_POINT stream type. BACKUP_SPARSE_BLOCK 0x00000009 Sparse file. This corresponds to the NTFS $DATA stream type for a sparse file. BACKUP_TXFS_DATA 0x0000000A Transactional NTFS (TxF) data stream. This corresponds to the NTFS $TXF_DATA stream type. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32StreamId.StreamAttributes
member.summary: Attributes of data to facilitate cross-operating system transfer. This member can be one or more of the following values: STREAM_MODIFIED_WHEN_READ 0x00000001 Attribute set if the stream contains data that is modified when read. Allows the backup application to know that verification of data will fail. STREAM_CONTAINS_SECURITY 0x00000002 Stream contains security data (general attributes). Allows the stream to be ignored on cross-operations restore.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32StreamId.StreamSize
member.summary: Size of data, in bytes.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.NativeMethods.Win32StreamId.StreamNameSize
member.summary: Length of the name of the alternative data stream, in bytes.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DosDeviceAttributes
member.summary: Defines the controllable aspects of the method.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DosDeviceAttributes.None
member.summary: Default.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DosDeviceAttributes.RawTargetPath
member.summary: Uses the targetPath string as is. Otherwise, it is converted from an MS-DOS path to a path.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DosDeviceAttributes.RemoveDefinition
member.summary: Removes the specified definition for the specified device. To determine which definition to remove, the function walks the list of mappings for the device, looking for a match of targetPath against a prefix of each mapping associated with this device. The first mapping that matches is the one removed, and then the function returns. If targetPath is null or a pointer to a null string, the function will remove the first mapping associated with the device and pop the most recent one pushed. If there is nothing left to pop, the device name will be removed. If this value is not specified, the string pointed to by the targetPath parameter will become the new mapping for this device.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DosDeviceAttributes.ExactMatchOnRemove
member.summary: If this value is specified along with RemoveDefinition, the function will use an exact match to determine which mapping to remove. Use this value to ensure that you do not delete something that you did not define.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DosDeviceAttributes.NoBroadcastSystem
member.summary: Do not broadcast the WM_SETTINGCHANGE message. By default, this message is broadcast to notify the shell and applications of the change.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions
member.summary: Flags that specify how a file is to be copied.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.None
member.summary: No CopyOptions used.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.FailIfExists
member.summary: The copy operation fails immediately if the target file already exists.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.Restartable
member.summary: Progress of the copy is tracked in the target file in case the copy fails. The failed copy can be restarted at a later time by specifying the same values for existing file name and new file name as those used in the call that failed. This can significantly slow down the copy operation as the new file may be flushed multiple times during the copy operation.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.OpenSourceForWrite
member.summary: The file is copied and the original file is opened for write access.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.AllowDecryptedDestination
member.summary: An attempt to copy an encrypted file will succeed even if the destination copy cannot be encrypted.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.CopySymlink
member.summary: If the source file is a symbolic link, the destination file is also a symbolic link pointing to the same file that the source symbolic link is pointing to.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions.NoBuffering
member.summary: The copy operation is performed using unbuffered I/O, bypassing system I/O cache resources. Recommended for very large file transfers.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyMoveProgressCallbackReason
member.summary: The reason that was called.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyMoveProgressCallbackReason.ChunkFinished
member.summary: Another part of the data file was copied.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyMoveProgressCallbackReason.StreamSwitch
member.summary: Another stream was created and is about to be copied. This is the callback reason given when the callback routine is first invoked.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.Directory.GetDirectories(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the names of subdirectories (including their paths) in the specified directory.
member.param: The path for which an array of subdirectory names is returned.
member.returns: An string[] array of the full names (including paths) of subdirectories in the specified path.
member.remarks: The EnumerateDirectories and GetDirectories methods differ as follows: When you use EnumerateDirectories, you can start enumerating the collection of names before the whole collection is returned; when you use GetDirectories, you must wait for the whole array of names to be returned before you can access the array. Therefore, when you are working with many files and directories, EnumerateDirectories can be more efficient.

Therefore, when you are working with many files and directories, EnumerateFiles can be more efficient.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.Directory.Move(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Moves a file or a directory and its contents to a new location.
member.param: The path of the file or directory to move.
The path to the new location for sourcePath. If sourcePath is a file, then destinationPath must also be a file name.
member.remarks: This method works across disk volumes.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.Directory.GetProperties(System.String)
member.summary:
Gets the properties of the particular folder without following any symbolic links or mount points.
Properties include aggregated info from of each encountered file system object,
plus additional ones: Total, File, Size, Error
Total: is the total number of enumerated objects.
File: is the total number of files. File is considered when object is neither nor .
Size: is the total size of enumerated objects.
Error: is the total number of errors encountered during enumeration.
member.remarks: Directory: is an object which has attribute without one.
member.param: The target directory.
member.returns: A dictionary mapping the keys mentioned above to their respective aggregated values.

true continue on errors.

that specify how the directory is to be moved. This parameter can be null.
A callback function that is called each time another portion of the file has been copied/moved. This parameter can be null.
The argument to be passed to the callback function. This parameter can be null.
member.remarks: Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

This Move method works across disk volumes, and it does not throw an exception if the source and destination are the same. Note that if you attempt to replace a file by moving a file of the same name into that directory, you get an IOException. You cannot use the Move method to overwrite an existing file.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.Directory.GetPropertiesInternal(Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.KernelTransaction,System.String,System.IO.SearchOption,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Unified method GetPropertiesInternal() to gets the properties of the particular folder without following any symbolic links or mount points. Properties include aggregated info from of each encountered file system object. Plus additional ones: "Total", "File", "Size" and "SizeCompressed".
Total: is the total number of enumerated objects.
File: is the total number of files. File is considered when object is neither nor .
Size: is the total size of enumerated objects.
Size: is the total compressed size of enumerated objects.
Error: is the total number of errors encountered during enumeration.
member.remarks: Directory: is an object which has attribute without one.
member.param: The transaction.
The target directory.
One of the enumeration values that specifies whether the search operation should include only the current directory or should include all subdirectories.
true continue on errors.
member.returns: A dictionary mapping the keys mentioned above to their respective aggregated values.

The path to test.
true it is assumed that is already a full path and will be used as is.
member.returns: true on success, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Note that this files may contain wildcards, such as '*'
Return value is true if the caller has the required permissions and path contains the name of an existing file; false otherwise.
This method also returns false if path is a null reference, an invalid path, or a zero-length string.
If the caller does not have sufficient permissions to read the specified file, no exception is thrown and the method returns false regardless of the existence of path.

member.summary: Gets or sets the time the current file or directory was last accessed.
member.returns: The time that the current file or directory was last accessed.
member.remarks: This value is expressed in local time.

When first called, calls Refresh and returns the cached information on APIs to get attributes and so on. On subsequent calls, you must call Refresh to get the latest copy of the information. If the file described in the object does not exist, this property will return 12:00 midnight, January 1, 1601 A.D. (C.E.) Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), adjusted to local time.

member.returns: The name of the parent directory, the name of the last directory in the hierarchy, or the name of a file, including the file name extension.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.CreateSubdirectory(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a subdirectory or subdirectories on the specified path. The specified path can be relative to this instance of the class.
member.param: The specified path. This cannot be a different disk volume.
member.returns: The last directory specified in .
member.remarks: Any and all directories specified in path are created, unless some part of path is invalid. The path parameter specifies a directory path, not a file path. If the subdirectory already exists, this method does nothing.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.CreateSubdirectory(System.String,System.Security.AccessControl.DirectorySecurity)

member.param: The specified path. This cannot be a different disk volume.
The security to apply.
member.returns: The last directory specified in .
member.remarks: Any and all directories specified in path are created, unless some part of path is invalid. The path parameter specifies a directory path, not a file path. If the subdirectory already exists, this method does nothing.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.GetDirectories
member.summary: Returns the subdirectories of the current directory.
member.returns: An array of objects. If there are no subdirectories, this method returns an empty array. This method is not recursive.
member.remarks: The EnumerateDirectories and GetDirectories methods differ as follows: When you use EnumerateDirectories, you can start enumerating the collection of names before the whole collection is returned; when you use GetDirectories, you must wait for the whole array of names to be returned before you can access the array. Therefore, when you are working with many files and directories, EnumerateDirectories can be more efficient.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.GetDirectories(System.String)
member.summary: Returns an array of directories in the current matching the given search criteria.
member.param: The path which has wildcard characters, for example, an asterisk () or a question mark ().
member.returns: An array of objects matching searchPattern. If there are no subdirectories, this method returns an empty array. This method is not recursive.
member.remarks: The EnumerateDirectories and GetDirectories methods differ as follows: When you use EnumerateDirectories, you can start enumerating the collection of names before the whole collection is returned; when you use GetDirectories, you must wait for the whole array of names to be returned before you can access the array. Therefore, when you are working with many files and directories, EnumerateDirectories can be more efficient.

member.remarks: The EnumerateDirectories and GetDirectories methods differ as follows: When you use EnumerateDirectories, you can start enumerating the collection of names before the whole collection is returned; when you use GetDirectories, you must wait for the whole array of names to be returned before you can access the array. Therefore, when you are working with many files and directories, EnumerateDirectories can be more efficient.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.GetFileSystemInfos
member.summary: Returns an array of strongly typed entries representing all the files and subdirectories in a directory.
member.returns: An array of strongly typed entries.
member.remarks: If there are no files or directories in the DirectoryInfo, this method returns an empty array. This method is not recursive. For subdirectories, the FileSystemInfo objects returned by this method can be cast to the derived class DirectoryInfo. Use the FileAttributes value returned by the Attributes property to determine whether the FileSystemInfo represents a file or a directory.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.MoveTo(System.String)
member.summary: Moves a instance and its contents to a new path.
member.param: The name and path to which to move this directory. The destination cannot be another disk volume or a directory with the identical name. It can be an existing directory to which you want to add this directory as a subdirectory.
member.remarks: Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.MoveTo(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves a instance and its contents to a new path.
member.param: The path to the new location for sourcePath.
true Delete destination folder if it exists; false Move will fail on existing folders or files.
member.remarks: This method works across disk volumes.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.DisableCompression
member.summary: Disables compression of the specified directory and the files in it.
member.remarks: This method disables the folder-compression attribute. It will not decompress the current contents of the folder. However, newly created files and folders will be uncompressed.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.DisableEncryption
member.summary: Disables encryption of the specified directory and the files in it. It does not affect encryption of subdirectories below the indicated directory.
member.returns: true on success, false otherwise.
member.remarks: This method will create/change the file "Desktop.ini" and wil set Encryption value: "Disable=0"

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.Decompress
member.summary: Decompresses an NTFS compressed directory.
member.remarks: This will only decompress the root items, non recursive.

member.summary: Decompresses an NTFS compressed directory.
member.param: One of the enumeration values that specifies whether the search operation should include only the current directory or should include all subdirectories.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.Decrypt
member.summary: Decrypts a directory that was encrypted by the current account using the Encrypt method.
member.remarks: This will only decrypt the root items, non recursive.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.EnableCompression
member.summary: Enables compression of the specified directory and the files in it.
member.remarks: This method enables the folder-compression attribute. It will not compress the current contents of the folder. However, newly created files and folders will be compressed.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.EnableEncryption
member.summary: Enables encryption of the specified directory and the files in it. It does not affect encryption of subdirectories below the indicated directory.
member.returns: true on success, false otherwise.
member.remarks: This method will create/change the file "Desktop.ini" and wil set Encryption value: "Disable=1"

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.Encrypt
member.summary: Encrypts a directory so that only the account used to encrypt the directory can decrypt it.
member.remarks: This will only encrypt the root items, non recursive.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.CreateSubdirectoryInternal(System.String,System.Security.AccessControl.DirectorySecurity)
member.summary: Unified method CreateSubdirectory() to create a subdirectory or subdirectories on the specified path. The specified path can be relative to this instance of the DirectoryInfo class.
member.param: The specified path. This cannot be a different disk volume or Universal Naming Convention (UNC) name.
The security to apply.
member.returns: The last directory specified in path as an object.
member.remarks: Any and all directories specified in path are created, unless some part of path is invalid. The path parameter specifies a directory path, not a file path. If the subdirectory already exists, this method does nothing.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.DirectoryInfo.CopyToMoveToInternal(System.String,System.Boolean,System.Nullable{Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions},System.Nullable{Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.MoveOptions},Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyMoveProgressCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Unified method CopyToMoveToInternal() to recursively copy folders and files from one root to another.
member.param: The destination folder path, of type string
true Preserves ACLs information.
that specify how the file is to be copied. This parameter can be null.
that specify how the file is to be moved. This parameter can be null.
A callback function that is called each time another portion of the file has been copied. This parameter can be null.
The argument to be passed to the callback function. This parameter can be null.
member.remarks: Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

This Move method works across disk volumes, and it does not throw an exception if the source and destination are the same. Note that if you attempt to replace a file by moving a file of the same name into that directory, you get an IOException. You cannot use the Move method to overwrite an existing file.

member.summary: Appends lines to a file, and then closes the file. If the specified file does not exist, this method creates a file, writes the specified lines to the file, and then closes the file.
member.param: The file to append the lines to. The file is created if it doesn't already exist.

member.remarks: The method creates the file if it doesn’t exist, but it doesn't create new directories. Therefore, the value of the path parameter must contain existing directories.

member.summary: Copies an existing file to a new file. Overwriting a file of the same name is not allowed.
member.param: The file to copy.
The name of the destination file. This cannot be a directory or an existing file.
member.remarks: The attributes of the original file are retained in the copied file.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.File.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified file exists.
member.param: The file to check. Note that this files may contain wildcards, such as '*'.
member.returns: true on success, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Note that this files may contain wildcards, such as '*'
true if the caller has the required permissions and path contains the name of an existing file; false otherwise.
This method also returns false if path is a null reference, an invalid path, or a zero-length string.
If the caller does not have sufficient permissions to read the specified file, no exception is thrown and the method returns false regardless of the existence of path.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.File.Exists(Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.KernelTransaction,System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified file exists.
member.param: The transaction.
The file to check. Note that this files may contain wildcards, such as '*'.
member.returns: true on success, false otherwise.
member.remarks: Note that this files may contain wildcards, such as '*'
Return value is true if the caller has the required permissions and path contains the name of an existing file; false otherwise.
This method also returns false if path is a null reference, an invalid path, or a zero-length string.
If the caller does not have sufficient permissions to read the specified file, no exception is thrown and the method returns false regardless of the existence of path.
A trailing backslash is not allowed and will be removed.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.File.GetAccessControl(System.String)

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.File.Move(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Moves a specified file to a new location, providing the option to specify a new file name.
member.param: The name of the file to move.
The new path for the file.
member.remarks: This method works across disk volumes.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.File.Move(System.String,System.String,Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.MoveOptions)
member.summary: Moves a specified file to a new location, providing the option to specify a new file name.
member.param: The name of the file to move.
The new path for the file.
The options.
member.remarks: This method works across disk volumes.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.File.Move(System.String,System.String,Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.MoveOptions,Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyMoveProgressCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Moves a file or directory, including its children. You can provide a callback function that receives progress notifications.

param.name: sourceFileName
param.para: The name of the existing file or directory on the local computer.
If specifies , the file cannot exist on a remote share because delayed operations are performed before the network is available.

param.name: destFileName
param.para: The new name of the file or directory on the local computer.
When moving a file, can be on a different file system or volume. If is on another drive, you must set the flag in .
When moving a directory, and must be on the same drive.

member.param: The move options.

A callback function that is called each time another portion of the file has been moved. The callback function can be useful if you provide a user interface that displays the progress of the operation. This parameter can be null.
An argument to be passed to the callback function. This parameter can be null.
member.returns: true when successfully moved, false otherwise or the operation was aborted.
member.remarks: This method works across disk volumes.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

member.param: The transaction.

The new path for the file.

member.remarks: This method works across disk volumes.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

that specify how the file is to be copied. This parameter can be null.
Flags that specify how the file is to be move. This parameter can be null.
A callback function that is called each time another portion of the file has been copied/moved. This parameter can be null.

member.remarks: This Move method works across disk volumes, and it does not throw an exception if the source and destination are the same. Note that if you attempt to replace a file by moving a file of the same name into that directory, you get an IOException. You cannot use the Move method to overwrite an existing file.

member.name: T:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.BackupFileStream
member.summary: The provides access to data associated with a specific file or directory, including security information and alternative data streams, for backup and restore operations.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.BackupFileStream.Skip(System.Int64)
member.summary: Skips ahead the specified number of bytes from the current stream.

remarks.para: This method represents the Win32 API implementation of BackupSeek.

Applications use the method to skip portions of a data stream that cause errors. This function does not seek across stream headers. For example, this function cannot be used to skip the stream name. If an application attempts to seek past the end of a substream, the function fails, the return value indicates the actual number of bytes the function seeks, and the file position is placed at the start of the next stream header.

member.param: The number of bytes to skip.
member.returns: The number of bytes actually skipped.

member.summary: Gets the file attributes.

member.summary: Gets a structure that specifies when a file or directory was created.
member.value: A structure that specifies when a file or directory was created.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.ByHandleFileInformation.LastAccessTime
member.summary: Gets a structure. For a file, the structure specifies the last time that a file is read from or written to. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. For both files and directories, the specified date is correct, but the time of day is always set to midnight. If the underlying file system does not support the last access time, this member is zero (0).
member.value: A structure that specifies when a file was last written to or the directory created.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.ByHandleFileInformation.LastWriteTime
member.summary: Gets a structure. For a file, the structure specifies the last time that a file is written to. For a directory, the structure specifies when the directory is created. If the underlying file system does not support the last access time, this member is zero (0).
member.value: A structure that specifies when a file was last written to or the directory created.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.ByHandleFileInformation.VolumeSerialNumber
member.summary: Gets the the serial number of the volume that contains a file.
member.value: The serial number of the volume that contains a file.

member.summary: Gets the size of the file.
member.value: The size of the file.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.ByHandleFileInformation.NumberOfLinks
member.summary: Gets the number of links to this file. For the FAT file system this member is always 1. For the NTFS file system, it can be more than 1.
member.value: The number of links to this file.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.ByHandleFileInformation.FileIndex
member.summary: Gets the unique identifier associated with the file. The identifier and the volume serial number uniquely identify a file on a single computer. To determine whether two open handles represent the same file, combine the identifier and the volume serial number for each file and compare them.
member.value: The unique identifier of the file.

member.name: P:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.FileIdBothDirectoryInfo.EndOfFile
member.summary: The absolute new end-of-file position as a byte offset from the start of the file to the end of the file. Because this value is zero-based, it actually refers to the first free byte in the file. In other words, EndOfFile is the offset to the byte that immediately follows the last valid byte in the file.

member.summary: The byte offset of the file within the parent directory. This member is undefined for file systems, such as NTFS, in which the position of a file within the parent directory is not fixed and can be changed at any time to maintain sort order.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.FileInfo.Replace(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces the contents of a specified file with the file described by the current object, deleting the original file, and creating a backup of the replaced file.
member.param: The name of a file to replace with the current file.
The name of a file with which to create a backup of the file described by the destinationFileName parameter.
member.returns: A object that encapsulates information about the file described by the destinationFileName parameter.
member.remarks: The Replace method replaces the contents of a specified file with the contents of the file described by the current object. It also creates a backup of the file that was replaced. Finally, it returns a new object that describes the overwritten file.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.FileInfo.Replace(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Replaces the contents of a specified file with the file described by the current object, deleting the original file, and creating a backup of the replaced file. Also specifies whether to ignore merge errors.
member.param: The name of a file to replace with the current file.
The name of a file with which to create a backup of the file described by the destinationFileName parameter.
true to ignore merge errors (such as attributes and ACLs) from the replaced file to the replacement file; false otherwise.
member.returns: A object that encapsulates information about the file described by the destinationFileName parameter.
member.remarks: The Replace method replaces the contents of a specified file with the contents of the file described by the current object. It also creates a backup of the file that was replaced. Finally, it returns a new object that describes the overwritten file.

member.name: M:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.FileInfo.CopyToMoveToInternal(System.String,System.Nullable{Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyOptions},System.Nullable{Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.MoveOptions},Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.CopyMoveProgressCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Recursive copying of folders and files from one root to another.

param.name: destFileName
param.para: A full path string to the destination directory

param.name: copyOptions
param.para: This parameter can be null. Use to specify how the file is to be copied.

param.name: moveOptions
param.para: This parameter can be null. Use that specify how the file is to be moved.

param.name: copyProgress
param.para: This parameter can be null. A callback function that is called each time another portion of the file has been copied.

param.name: userProgressData
param.para: This parameter can be null. The argument to be passed to the callback function.

member.returns: A new file with a fully qualified path. Returns null on failure.
member.remarks: The attributes of the original file are retained in the copied file.

Whenever possible, avoid using short file names (such as XXXXXX~1.XXX) with this method. If two files have equivalent short file names then this method may fail and raise an exception and/or result in undesirable behavior

This Move method works across disk volumes, and it does not throw an exception if the source and destination are the same. Note that if you attempt to replace a file by moving a file of the same name into that directory, you get an IOException. You cannot use the Move method to overwrite an existing file.

member.summary: Specifies how the operating system should open a file.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.None
member.summary: None of the file attributes specified.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.ReadOnly
member.summary: The file is read only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to or delete it.
member.remarks: Equals 1

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Hidden
member.summary: The file is hidden. Do not include it in an ordinary directory listing.
member.remarks: Equals 2

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.System
member.summary: The file is part of or used exclusively by an operating system.
member.remarks: Equals 4

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Directory
member.summary: The handle that identifies a directory.
member.remarks: Equals 16

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Archive
member.summary: The file should be archived. Applications use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal.
member.remarks: Equals 32

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Device
member.summary: The file should be archived. Applications use this attribute to mark files for backup or removal.
member.remarks: Equals 64

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Normal
member.summary: The file does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only if used alone.
member.remarks: Equals 128

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Temporary
member.summary: The file is being used for temporary storage.
member.remarks: Equals 256

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.SparseFile
member.summary: A file that is a sparse file.
member.remarks: Equals 512

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.ReparsePoint
member.summary: A file or directory that has an associated reparse point, or a file that is a symbolic link.
member.remarks: Equals 1024

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Compressed
member.summary: A file or directory that is compressed. For a file, all of the data in the file is compressed. For a directory, compression is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.
member.remarks: Equals 2048

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Offline
member.summary: The data of a file is not immediately available. This attribute indicates that file data is physically moved to offline storage. This attribute is used by Remote Storage, the hierarchical storage management software. Applications should not arbitrarily change this attribute.
member.remarks: Equals 4096

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.NotContentIndexed
member.summary: The file or directory is not to be indexed by the content indexing service.
member.remarks: Equals 8192

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Encrypted
member.summary: The file or directory is encrypted. For a file, this means that all data in the file is encrypted. For a directory, this means that encryption is the default for newly created files and subdirectories.
member.remarks: Equals 16384

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.IntegrityStream
member.summary: (0x8000) The directory or user data stream is configured with integrity (only supported on ReFS volumes). It is not included in an ordinary directory listing. The integrity setting persists with the file if it's renamed. If a file is copied the destination file will have integrity set if either the source file or destination directory have integrity set.
member.remarks: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.NoScrubData
member.summary: (0x20000) The user data stream not to be read by the background data integrity scanner (AKA scrubber). When set on a directory it only provides inheritance. This flag is only supported on Storage Spaces and ReFS volumes. It is not included in an ordinary directory listing.
member.remarks: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.OpenNoRecall
member.summary: (0x100000) The file data is requested, but it should continue to be located in remote storage. It should not be transported back to local storage. This flag is for use by remote storage systems.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.OpenReparsePoint
member.summary: (0x200000) Normal reparse point processing will not occur; an attempt to open the reparse point will be made. When a file is opened, a file handle is returned, whether or not the filter that controls the reparse point is operational. See MSDN documentation for more information.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.PosixSemantics
member.summary: (0x1000000) Access will occur according to POSIX rules. This includes allowing multiple files with names, differing only in case, for file systems that support that naming. Use care when using this option, because files created with this flag may not be accessible by applications that are written for MS-DOS or 16-bit Windows.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.BackupSemantics
member.summary: (0x2000000) The file is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation. The system ensures that the calling process overrides file security checks when the process has SE_BACKUP_NAME and SE_RESTORE_NAME privileges. You must set this flag to obtain a handle to a directory. A directory handle can be passed to some functions instead of a file handle.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.DeleteOnClose
member.summary: The file is to be deleted immediately after all of its handles are closed, which includes the specified handle and any other open or duplicated handles. If there are existing open handles to a file, the call fails unless they were all opened with the share mode. Subsequent open requests for the file fail, unless the share mode is specified.
member.remarks: Equals 67108864

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.SequentialScan
member.summary: Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching.
member.remarks: Equals 134217728

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.RandomAccess
member.summary: Access is intended to be random. The system can use this as a hint to optimize file caching.
member.remarks: Equals 268435456

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.NoBuffering
member.summary: (0x20000000) There are strict requirements for successfully working with files opened with the flag, for details see the section on "File Buffering" in the online MSDN documentation.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.Overlapped
member.summary: The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O.

member.name: F:Alphaleonis.Win32.Filesystem.EFileAttributes.WriteThrough
member.summary: (0x80000000) Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to disk.
member.remarks: Equals .NET -2147483648
